title: Parkinson's Disease — Motor Fluctuations and Dyskinesia
scope: ** Management of motor fluctuations (wearing off, on-off fluctuations, delayed on, dose failures) and dyskinesia (peak-dose, diphasic, off-period dystonia) in established Parkinson's disease patients on dopaminergic therapy. Includes pharmacologic optimization, advanced therapies (DBS, pump therapies), and management of acute off-state emergencies. Excludes initial diagnosis and early management of PD (see Parkinson's Disease — New Diagnosis template), PD dementia, and PD psychosis (separate templates).

Core Labs (Baseline Assessment).rationale: Baseline; anemia exacerbating fatigue; COMT inhibitor monitoring (hepatic effects)
Electrolytes; renal function (dopamine agonist dose adjustment); dehydration in off states
Baseline before COMT inhibitors (entacapone, opicapone); tolcapone requires regular monitoring
Hypothyroidism mimicking bradykinesia and fatigue; hyperthyroidism causing tremor
B12 deficiency (common in elderly PD patients); exacerbates neuropathy and cognitive issues
Deficiency extremely common in PD (fall risk, bone health for DBS candidates)

Extended Labs.rationale: Iron deficiency (restless legs overlap); ferritin <75 may warrant supplementation in PD patients with sleep-related motor symptoms
Levodopa metabolism produces homocysteine; elevated levels associated with cognitive decline and vascular risk in PD
Co-factor in homocysteine metabolism; supplement if homocysteine elevated
Baseline before initiating dopamine agonists (QTc assessment); domperidone QTc monitoring; cardiac arrhythmia evaluation
Extended Labs.target: Normal sinus rhythm; QTc <470 ms (women) or <450 ms (men)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Research or complex fluctuations only; correlate plasma levels with clinical state
Rare/Specialized.target: Document therapeutic window; identify absorption issues

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If dose failures/delayed on suspected from gastroparesis (common in PD)
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal emptying time; delayed = gastroparesis contributing to dose failures

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Only if diagnosis uncertain (atypical features, drug-induced parkinsonism query); NOT needed for typical PD motor fluctuations
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced striatal uptake confirms presynaptic dopaminergic deficit

Essential Studies.timing: Daily for 1-2 weeks before each clinic visit; gold standard for quantifying motor fluctuations
Essential Studies.target: Hours of on time, off time, on with troublesome dyskinesia; identify patterns relative to dosing
Essential Studies.contraindications: Cognitive impairment limiting diary accuracy (use caregiver-assisted)

Essential Studies.item: Unified PD Rating Scale Part III (MDS-UPDRS)
Essential Studies.timing: Each clinic visit; in on-state and off-state if possible
Essential Studies.target: Score trend; treatment response; guide medication adjustments

Extended Studies.timing: Pre-DBS planning; atypical features evaluation; rule out structural pathology
Extended Studies.target: No vascular parkinsonism; no NPH; no structural lesion; adequate brain volume for DBS targeting

Extended Studies.timing: Pre-DBS evaluation; quantify levodopa responsiveness; dose optimization
Extended Studies.target: >30% improvement in MDS-UPDRS Part III = good DBS candidate; documents best "on" state
Extended Studies.contraindications: Severe dyskinesia risk during supraphysiologic dosing

Extended Studies.timing: Pre-DBS evaluation; cognitive baseline; assess for PD dementia (relative DBS contraindication)
Extended Studies.target: MoCA >=26 preferred for DBS; no significant dementia

Rare/Specialized.timing: Objective motor fluctuation quantification; supplement patient diary; research settings
Rare/Specialized.target: Continuous objective on/off/dyskinesia tracking; correlate with dosing times

Rare/Specialized.timing: Chronic delayed on / dose failures not explained by dietary protein; suspected gastroparesis

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).indication: Acute rescue for severe off episodes; akinetic crisis; inability to take oral medications

dosing.instructions: Test dose 2 mg SQ; usual rescue dose 2-6 mg SQ; onset 10-20 min; can repeat after 2 hours; pretreat with trimethobenzamide 300 mg PO TID starting 3 days before first dose to prevent nausea

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).contraindications: Concurrent use of 5-HT3 antagonists (ondansetron); severe hepatic or renal impairment; hypersensitivity
Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).monitoring: BP (orthostatic); nausea; QTc (obtain baseline ECG); injection site reactions; somnolence

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).item: Levodopa/carbidopa oral dissolution (Parcopa or generic ODT)
Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).indication: Off episode with difficulty swallowing; faster onset than standard tablet

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa oral dissolution (Parcopa or generic ODT) 100/25 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 100/25 mg orally disintegrating tablet; dissolves on tongue; absorption may be slightly faster than standard tablet; place on tongue without water
dosing.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa oral dissolution (Parcopa or generic ODT) 100/25 mg PO

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).indication: Rescue for off episodes in patients already on levodopa; rapid onset (10-15 min)

dosing.instructions: 84 mg levodopa inhalation powder; max 5 doses/day (420 mg); onset within 10-15 minutes; intended as adjunct rescue, not replacement for oral levodopa

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).contraindications: Concurrent non-selective MAOIs; asthma/COPD (bronchospasm risk); hypersensitivity
Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).monitoring: FEV1 (baseline pulmonary function); dyskinesia; nausea; cough; URI symptoms

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).item: Resume home PD medications (do NOT hold levodopa in hospital)
Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).indication: All hospitalized PD patients; medication must be given on time

doseOptions.orderSentence: Resume home PD medications (do NOT hold levodopa in hospital) Home dose PO

dosing.instructions: Critical: administer levodopa at EXACT home times, not on standard medication pass schedule; late doses cause severe off states; use NG tube if NPO; PD medications should NEVER be abruptly stopped
dosing.orderSentence: Resume home PD medications (do NOT hold levodopa in hospital) Home dose PO

Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).contraindications: Active psychosis (relative for dopamine agonists); post-operative nausea (use domperidone, NOT metoclopramide or prochlorperazine)
Acute/Emergent (Off-State Emergency).monitoring: Motor state; NPO patients — arrange alternative route; monitor for NMS if medications inadvertently held

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off with predictable end-of-dose deterioration

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa — increase frequency (shorter intervals) Same total daily dose PO

dosing.instructions: Decrease interval from TID to QID or Q3h; keep individual doses the same or slightly reduce each dose; goal: more continuous dopaminergic stimulation without increasing total daily levodopa
dosing.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa — increase frequency (shorter intervals) Same total daily dose PO

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Dyskinesia; off time; motor diary; nausea

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; overnight/early morning off periods; smoother plasma levels

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa extended-release (Sinemet CR or Rytary) CR: 200/50 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Sinemet CR 200/50 TID-QID (bioavailability ~70% of IR, adjust dose upward); Rytary 95/23.75-390/97.5 mg TID-QID (ER capsule with beads); longer duration per dose but less predictable peak
dosing.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa extended-release (Sinemet CR or Rytary) CR: 200/50 mg PO

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Same as IR levodopa; do not crush CR formulations
Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Off time; dyskinesia; unpredictable response (CR can have variable absorption)

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; extend levodopa duration by blocking peripheral COMT metabolism

dosing.instructions: 200 mg with each levodopa dose; max 8 doses/day (1600 mg); extends levodopa half-life by ~30%; combination tablet Stalevo available

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; pheochromocytoma; concurrent non-selective MAOIs
Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Dyskinesia (may need to reduce levodopa 10-30%); diarrhea; urine discoloration (orange-brown); LFTs

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; once-daily COMT inhibitor; more convenient than entacapone

dosing.instructions: 50 mg once daily at bedtime; take at least 1 hour before or after levodopa; long-acting peripheral COMT inhibitor

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; pheochromocytoma; concurrent non-selective MAOIs
Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Dyskinesia (reduce levodopa if needed); diarrhea; hallucinations; orthostatic hypotension

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; adjunct to levodopa; MAO-B inhibitor extends dopamine availability

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg daily; can use as monotherapy in early PD or adjunct to levodopa; irreversible selective MAO-B inhibitor

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Concurrent meperidine, tramadol, methadone, MAOIs, cyclobenzaprine; St. John's wort
Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Serotonin syndrome (with concurrent serotonergic drugs); orthostatic hypotension; dyskinesia; impulse control disorders

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; dual mechanism (MAO-B inhibition + glutamate release modulation)

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; increase to 100 mg daily after 2 weeks if needed; adjunct to levodopa; additional anti-dyskinetic effect via glutamate modulation

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent opioids (meperidine, tramadol), MAOIs, dextromethorphan, cyclobenzaprine
Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.monitoring: Dyskinesia; nausea; insomnia; serotonin syndrome risk with serotonergic drugs

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.indication: Wearing off; adenosine A2A receptor antagonist; adjunct to levodopa; non-dopaminergic mechanism

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; increase to 40 mg daily if needed; first-in-class adenosine receptor antagonist; reduces off time via non-dopaminergic pathway

Wearing-Off Management (First-Line Adjus.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors

Dyskinesia Management.indication: Peak-dose dyskinesia; reduce peak dopamine levels while maintaining frequency

doseOptions.orderSentence: Reduce individual levodopa dose Reduce by 25-50 mg per dose PO

dosing.instructions: Lower each levodopa dose by 25-50 mg while maintaining or increasing frequency; trade: may increase off time
dosing.orderSentence: Reduce individual levodopa dose Reduce by 25-50 mg per dose PO

Dyskinesia Management.monitoring: Off time vs dyskinesia diary; functional impact

Dyskinesia Management.indication: Moderate-severe peak-dose dyskinesia; only FDA-approved treatment for levodopa-induced dyskinesia

dosing.instructions: Start 137 mg qHS; increase to 274 mg qHS after 1 week; extended-release formulation specifically for dyskinesia; take at bedtime

Dyskinesia Management.contraindications: GFR <15; concurrent live vaccines; end-stage renal disease
Dyskinesia Management.monitoring: Hallucinations; livedo reticularis; peripheral edema; renal function (dose adjust GFR 15-60); falls; corneal edema (ophthalmologic monitoring)

Dyskinesia Management.indication: Dyskinesia; alternative when ER unavailable; also treats off-period akinesia

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg daily; titrate to 100 mg BID-TID; max 400 mg/day; renal dose adjustment required

Dyskinesia Management.contraindications: Same as amantadine ER; dose adjust for renal impairment
Dyskinesia Management.monitoring: Same as ER; taper gradually (do not stop abruptly)

Dyskinesia Management.indication: Severe refractory dyskinesia not responsive to amantadine or levodopa adjustment; also treats PD psychosis

dosing.instructions: Start 6.25 mg qHS; increase slowly by 6.25 mg q1-2 weeks; max 50 mg/day for dyskinesia; REMS program required (weekly CBC first 6 months)

Dyskinesia Management.contraindications: Seizure disorder; agranulocytosis history; concurrent myelosuppressive agents
Dyskinesia Management.monitoring: ANC weekly x6 months, then biweekly x6 months, then monthly; metabolic syndrome; sedation; sialorrhea

Advanced Therapies.item: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) — STN or GPi (CPT 61863)
Advanced Therapies.indication: Motor fluctuations and/or dyskinesia refractory to optimal medical management; good levodopa responsiveness (>30% UPDRS improvement); adequate cognition (MoCA >=26); disease duration typically >=4 years

doseOptions.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) — STN or GPi (CPT 61863) Surgical implantation Surgical

dosing.instructions: STN-DBS (bilateral) or GPi-DBS; programming begins 2-4 weeks post-implant; medication adjustment concurrent with programming; STN-DBS allows greater medication reduction; GPi-DBS has more direct anti-dyskinetic effect
dosing.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) — STN or GPi (CPT 61863) Surgical implantation Surgical

Advanced Therapies.contraindications: Dementia (MoCA <21); active psychiatric illness; atypical parkinsonism (MSA, PSP, CBD); coagulopathy; medical instability for surgery; unrealistic expectations
Advanced Therapies.monitoring: Post-op imaging; device programming (multiple sessions); medication adjustment; neuropsychological monitoring; device battery life; infection

Advanced Therapies.indication: Severe motor fluctuations in advanced PD not candidates for DBS or who prefer non-surgical brain approach

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa intestinal gel (Duopa/Duodopa) Continuous infusion Enteral

dosing.instructions: Delivered via PEG-J tube to jejunum; continuous daytime infusion over 16 hours; provides steady levodopa levels; bypasses gastric emptying; requires permanent PEG-J tube
dosing.orderSentence: Levodopa/carbidopa intestinal gel (Duopa/Duodopa) Continuous infusion Enteral

Advanced Therapies.contraindications: Same as levodopa; unable to manage pump; severe dementia; anatomic contraindication to PEG
Advanced Therapies.monitoring: Tube complications (obstruction, migration, infection); dyskinesia; neuropathy (monitor B12/folate/homocysteine); device malfunction

Advanced Therapies.item: Subcutaneous apomorphine continuous infusion (Kynmobi pump or foslevodopa/foscarbidopa)
Advanced Therapies.indication: Severe motor fluctuations; DBS not appropriate; alternative to Duopa

doseOptions.orderSentence: Subcutaneous apomorphine continuous infusion (Kynmobi pump or foslevodopa/foscarbidopa) Continuous SQ

dosing.instructions: Subcutaneous apomorphine pump: start 1 mg/hr, titrate to effect (2-6 mg/hr); foslevodopa/foscarbidopa (Produodopa): continuous SQ infusion via pump; provides continuous dopaminergic stimulation
dosing.orderSentence: Subcutaneous apomorphine continuous infusion (Kynmobi pump or foslevodopa/foscarbidopa) Continuous SQ

Advanced Therapies.contraindications: Concurrent 5-HT3 antagonists (for apomorphine); injection site reactions
Advanced Therapies.monitoring: BP; injection site nodules; somnolence; QTc; psychiatric symptoms; hemolytic anemia (apomorphine)

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders specialist for optimization of fluctuations and dyskinesia; advanced therapy evaluation (DBS, pump therapies); complex medication management
DBS surgical team evaluation (neurosurgeon + movement disorders neurologist) if motor fluctuations or dyskinesia are refractory to optimized medical management and patient meets candidacy criteria
Physical therapy for gait and balance training, fall prevention, exercise prescription (PD-specific programs: LSVT BIG, PWR! Moves, boxing, dance)
Speech therapy (LSVT LOUD) for hypophonia and speech clarity — common in advancing PD
Occupational therapy for ADL strategies during off periods, adaptive equipment, and home safety assessment
Psychiatry/psychology for depression, anxiety, impulse control disorders (associated with dopamine agonists), and adjustment to disease progression
Nutrition/dietitian for protein redistribution diet (protein competes with levodopa for absorption); ensure adequate hydration and fiber for constipation management

Patient Instructions.item: Take levodopa on time, every time — even small delays can trigger off episodes; set multiple alarms; bring medications to all appointments and hospital stays

Take levodopa 30-60 minutes before meals or 1-2 hours after meals for best absorption — protein (amino acids) competes with levodopa for intestinal absorption; consider a protein redistribution diet (low protein during the day, larger protein serving at dinner)

Never stop PD medications abruptly — sudden discontinuation can cause neuroleptic malignant-like syndrome (hyperthermia, rigidity, autonomic instability, altered consciousness) which is life-threatening

Keep an on/off motor diary for 1-2 weeks before each clinic visit — record time of each medication dose, hours of good mobility (on), hours of poor mobility (off), and hours of involuntary movements (dyskinesia)

Avoid medications that block dopamine: metoclopramide (Reglan), prochlorperazine (Compazine), promethazine (Phenergan), haloperidol, droperidol — these will dramatically worsen PD symptoms; use ondansetron for nausea (unless on apomorphine) or domperidone if available
Exercise regularly (walking, cycling, boxing, dance, swimming) — exercise is neuroprotective and improves motor function, balance, and quality of life in PD
Report new involuntary movements (dyskinesia), hallucinations, gambling/spending/sexual urges (impulse control disorders), or excessive daytime sleepiness to your movement disorders team

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Exercise 30-60 minutes daily, 5 days/week: PD-specific programs (LSVT BIG, Rock Steady Boxing, PD Warrior, dance for PD) provide greatest benefit; exercise is the most evidence-based lifestyle intervention for PD
Protein redistribution diet: keep daytime protein intake low (20-30 g) to optimize levodopa absorption; consume remaining protein at evening meal when motor function is less critical

Prevent falls: remove throw rugs; install grab bars; use nightlights; avoid carrying objects while walking; use assistive devices (cane, walker) when needed; address freezing of gait with cues (counting, laser pointer, metronome)
Maintain social engagement and cognitive stimulation — social isolation accelerates cognitive decline in PD; support groups, hobbies, and structured activities are beneficial

Manage constipation proactively: high fiber diet (25-30 g/day), adequate hydration (2L/day), polyethylene glycol (Miralax) 17 g daily — constipation delays gastric emptying and worsens levodopa absorption
Optimize sleep hygiene: consistent sleep/wake times; melatonin 3-5 mg for insomnia; treat REM sleep behavior disorder if present; good sleep improves daytime motor function

differential.features: Poor or waning levodopa response; atypical features (early falls in PSP, autonomic failure in MSA, asymmetric apraxia in CBD); faster progression; do NOT develop typical wearing-off pattern
differential.tests: Clinical diagnostic criteria; MRI (hot cross bun in MSA, hummingbird in PSP); DaTscan (does not distinguish PD from atypical)

differential.features: Temporal relationship to dopamine-blocking medications (antipsychotics, antiemetics); bilateral symmetric onset; no levodopa response or motor fluctuations
differential.tests: Medication reconciliation; DaTscan (normal in drug-induced); symptoms resolve with drug withdrawal (weeks-months)

differential.features: Hallucinations, delusions, agitation — may be confused with "off" state psychiatric symptoms; medication-related vs disease-related
differential.tests: Temporal relationship to dopamine agonist dose changes; visual hallucinations (VH); clear sensorium (PD psychosis) vs confusion (delirium)

differential.features: Apathy, psychomotor retardation, and withdrawal may mimic off-state akinesia; should be evaluated as comorbidity, not just motor fluctuation
differential.tests: Depression screening (GDS, PHQ-9); symptoms present regardless of on/off state; trial of antidepressant

differential.features: Weakness, light-headedness, near-syncope when standing may be confused with off-state motor decline; PD and medications both cause OH
differential.tests: Orthostatic vital signs; symptoms correlate with BP drop, not motor state; treatment: fludrocortisone, midodrine, droxidopa

differential.features: Delayed gastric emptying causes erratic levodopa absorption → dose failures and unpredictable on/off; common in PD
differential.tests: Gastric emptying study; trial of domperidone or liquid levodopa preparations

differential.features: Sudden transient inability to initiate or continue walking; may be on-state freezing (medication-resistant) or off-state freezing; distinct from motor fluctuation per se
differential.tests: Motor diary documenting freezing timing relative to medication doses; observe gait

evidence.recommendation: MDS Evidence-Based Medicine Review of Treatments for Motor Symptoms in PD
Levodopa fractionation (shorter intervals) is first approach to wearing off
Entacapone as adjunct to levodopa reduces off time by ~1 hour/day
STN-DBS improves motor fluctuations, off time, and quality of life in advanced PD
Apomorphine SC injection provides rapid rescue from off episodes (onset 10-20 min)
Inhaled levodopa (Inbrija) provides rapid rescue for off episodes
Safinamide provides additional off-time reduction and anti-dyskinetic benefit via dual mechanism
Istradefylline (adenosine A2A antagonist) reduces off time as adjunct to levodopa
Protein redistribution diet improves levodopa absorption and reduces off time

monitoring.frequency: Continuously between visits; review at each visit
monitoring.action: Adjust levodopa timing/dose; add adjunct (COMT-I, MAO-B-I); consider advanced therapies if refractory

monitoring.item: MDS-UPDRS Part III (motor exam) in defined on-state
monitoring.action: Medication adjustment; consider DBS referral if significantly worsening despite optimization
Adjust strategy; escalate to advanced therapies
Optimize hydration/salt; reduce dopamine agonist if contributor; add fludrocortisone/midodrine

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q2-4 weeks for tolcapone; q6-12 months for entacapone/opicapone
monitoring.action: Reduce dose; discontinue if >3x ULN or symptoms; tolcapone: mandatory monitoring

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; especially on dopamine agonists
monitoring.action: Reduce or discontinue dopamine agonist; behavioral counseling; consider amantadine
Evaluate for PDD; adjust medications (reduce anticholinergics, cautious with amantadine); neuropsychological testing

monitoring.frequency: Q3-6 months post-implant; annual once stable
monitoring.action: Reprogram; battery replacement (non-rechargeable q3-5 years; rechargeable q15-25 years)

disposition.criteria: Off episode resolved with rescue medication; able to resume home medication schedule; no aspiration or fall-related injury; follow-up with movement disorders specialist within 1-2 weeks
Prolonged off state not responding to home medications; unable to take oral medications (need for NG tube or SQ apomorphine); fall requiring monitoring; dehydration

Akinetic crisis (inability to move, swallow, or protect airway); NMS-like syndrome from medication interruption; elective DBS surgery; Duopa pump placement; severe dehydration or aspiration pneumonia in off state

Neuroleptic malignant-like syndrome (abrupt PD medication discontinuation: hyperthermia >38.5°C, severe rigidity, autonomic instability); aspiration with respiratory failure; akinetic crisis with airway compromise
Motor fluctuations: q2-4 weeks during active adjustment; stable: q3-6 months; DBS programming: weekly-biweekly initially, then q3 months; advanced therapy titration: q2-4 weeks
